original_title: Sri Lanka wants to see Indian rupee used like the dollar: President
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka would like to see the Indian rupee used as much as the US dollar, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has told a business forum of Indian chief executives.
The “Sri Lankan government would want to see the Indian rupee used as much as the dollar,” Wickremesighe was quoted as saying at a CEO foru.
“It makes no difference to us if India becomes a common currency,” Wickremesinghe was quoted as saying at a forum of Indian chief executives.
“We’ll have to figure out how to go about it. So that is what we must do. We must become more open to the outside world.”
President was responding to a comment by T S Prakash, President of the Indian CEO Forum, on the circulation of Indian currency in Sri Lanka, the statement said.
India has been pushing to use the Indian rupee in cross-border transactions, and several banks had started VOSTRO accounts.
However, the success of cross border transactions involve the willingness of Indian exporters to accept the Indian currency, analysts say.
In Sri Lanka, due to the willingness of expatriate worker families to accept rupees, there is an active VOSTRO volume with the Middle East.
In Sri Lanka foreign currencies are not legal tender, but economists have advocated dollarization as a solution to monetary instability and default.
Sri Lanka dollarization, currency competition can end depreciation, instability: Lawrence White
Sri Lanka should prepare to float, and promote parallel dollarization: Bellwether

Dollarized countries have low nominal interest rates, low inflation, low debt to GDP ratios of about 40 percent and effective ‘dollar’ growth. Cambodia is one of the latest countries to see the phenomenon in action.

Without a depreciating currency it would not be possible to impose regressive inflation taxes on the poorest in society through ‘macro-economic policy’ or rate cuts enforced with open market operations.
Without standing liquidity facilities or sterilized dollar sales banks also lose the ability to give loans without deposits, contributing to both economic and banking system stability.
In Sri Lanka a China-backed special economic zone is to be ‘dollarized’ with multiple currencies including the Yuan and will be free from high inflation and forex shortages.

Before the Reserve Bank of India was nationalized and started to collapse under ‘macro-economic policies’ of the five year plans, the Indian rupee was the base currency in Sri Lanka, in South Asian countries and several Middle Eastern countries which shifted to currency board-like arrangements. (Colombo/July17/2023)
